The reason you get droplets is due to a phenomenon called Rayleigh Instability. This causes a smooth film of water on a fibre to break up into droplets. The droplets stick to the fibres of the web due to capillary forces.

For the shockwave, and this is just my guess: It's an acoustic wave being created from the impact of the baseball against the plastic shell; The shell compresses and formed a wave, similar to water, and that translates out to the air. This wave also explains the sprinkles breaking into small pieces as well, as the air pressure inside the bottle from just the impact being conveyed by the plastic is causing everything to break, and in the microseconds following we see that ultimate reaction. It is also interesting to note that the sprinkles in the bottom-right corner of the bottle do not break apart, suggesting that the other material absorbs and breaks that wave rather quickly, and the bottle stretching also helps diffuse that energy. To return back to the point, this would form at any high-speed impact and I'd recommend setting up a microphone to capture any inaudible sound waves that are below the hearing range to confirm this.

At 15:57 the ball penetrates clean through the center of the gong, and neither the gong or its frame move at all. At 15:59 we see the white air pressure wind blowing from the cannon which is the force that blasts the gong and its frame off its table into the backstop. But the fascinating shot is at 15:57 because the projectile ball goes through the gong so fast that it doesn't even

move or disturb the gong in the slightest way from its totally stationary position while hanging like a pendulum from its two tiny strings from the frame.

One would think that the momentum or inertia of the ball, which has a very large surface area compared to a bullet, would at least move the gong and its frame a bit, if not knock it over as it penetrated through, but in fact it did not !!

The crew continued to focus on the optics of the shot while either ignoring or leaving out the physics of this fascinating phenomenon.

@13:33 ff - In the somewhat erratic and anecdotal 'research' (experience) of my life, one notes penetration of a single hard surface - like a steel plate, a car door or a gong - seems to be better punctured by a high velocity projectile with weight not a primary consideration. The relatively 'clean' hole in the gong seems to be consistent with my expectations. However, it seems the energy in the projectile is not all used up against the 'obstruction'.
I am curious about the effect of a solid steel ball the same size as the baseball. Obviously, the initial velocity would be lessened, but the retained velocity would be greater. I rather expect such a projectile to penetrate further into a homologous material (a hay bale or swimming pool full of water).
As you may have deduced, my main hobby is firearm and ballistic research.
Seeing the slow-mo of the ball penetrating the gong, one is reminded of the shape factor. The ball pushes the metal of the gong so fast the rest of the gong cannot accelerate as fast as the area directly affected. But the round shape pushes the contact area and stretches the metal. That interaction removes energy from the ball, reducing the velocity. A pointed projectile will penetrate the surface, passing through and retaining more energy and velocity.
It suddenly occurs to me that as a weapons designer, you already know all this.

It's REALLY interesting why the gong barely moved on impact, if at all - I'd love to know the answer why, that's the craziest bit of the video for me - there seems to be almost zero transference of kinetic energy to the gong. Hi, percussionist here. That's a very low quality gong—more of a cymbal really. If you whack a real orchestral gong like you did at the beginning, all you get is a dull thud. A symphonic gong is considerably thicker and you have to start it vibrating for awhile before you can get it to flash over into the the full gong sound. It's tricky to time it right. I think a real gong could do better. It'll cost you around $1-2k, though, depending on the diameter of the instrument.

Destin asked why dew beads up like that on spider webs. The answer is very complicated, but Nature has a good article that partially explains it. It seems to come down to "joints" in the web that have very high surface area, so they can support much larger drops. Water is drawn to them along the web by cohesion.

my theory for the dew on the spider web:
Spider webs are made of a conglomeration of proteins, and these proteins are primarily composed of the amino acids alanine and glycine. Both of these have hydrophobic properties, which allow for the formation of nucleation points, further allowing for droplets to be suspended on the protein macro-strands that is the spider silk. Additionally, I think the beading/pearling effect is primarily due to surface tension of small quantities of water along with hydrogen bonding and van der Waals forces. Just my take on it.

I think they blow apart because the pressure is transmitted molecule to molecule until it gets to the end. After that it the force cannot be transmitted any further, so it goes from a compression force to a tensile force which rips the candy apart.
Does a vacuum improve the velocity of every barreled weapon?

The pressure to speed graph function = x^0.5 (square root of the pressure )

Proof :
Work = force * distance = 0.5 * mass * velocity^2
=> (pressure * area) * distance = 0.5 * mass * velocity^2
Rearranging:
Velocity = (2 * area * distance /mass )^0.5 * pressure^0.5 ,
(2 * area * distance /mass)^0.5 is a constant for the same canon and ball
So velocity = constant * pressure^0.5

Of course this ignores friction and air resistance, if you take them into account I think the friction will cause the ball to deform inside the canon which will at high enough pressure will cause the ball to tear and break apart in the canon, reducing the effective distance that the ball is being pushed on by the pressure , which will eventually create a point were if you increase the pressure the exit velocity will actually decrease .

So, let's try an experiment and see if you can spin the ball in flight.  You had mentioned that you were throwing knuckle balls.  Let's throw a curve.  The laces can provide an indication of rotational rate.  The final deflection of the curve ball can be correlated with the pressure differential on either side of the ball.  So, you might be able to control the curve arc.  Now, this going supersonic would be interesting and getting the rotation could be tricky.  A schlieren camera view perpendicular to the curve arc could show some interesting compression effects as well.  Perhaps something of a baseball sized "sabot" round with a golf ball inside could do it.  Anyway, my son and I enjoy the channel.  Keep up the good work.

In physics they refer to this limit of flexibility of metal as hypo-plasticity. The velocity of impact actually affects the response of the gong. A slower velocity can dent even a rigid piece of metal. The velocity determines the sharpness of the reactive movement of the receiving metal. The material of the probe also plays a role in the resulting impact. Oh this sort of stuff is so fun. I read a bunch of the comments, and replied to one about the "air".
To the gong enthusiasts, it would actually only take 2 gongs to stop the projectile. But that depends on how you have it set up.

If you placed the gongs pressed up to one another bundled together, yes it might take 3-5. Depends on how close they are, how thick the gongs are, what type/quality of metal, etc. etc. (Hint: if you held these together with vice clamps to press them close, you should probably take cover as the vice clamps would become potential projectiles upon impact of the gong sandwich, depending on how many gongs you lined up in the sandwich. More = less risk.)

If you have 2 gongs, on their stands, directly lined up one behind each other, it would only take 2 to stop it. The projectile would not penetrate the 2nd gong.
Reason: Upon impact of the 1st gong, most of the kinetic energy is dispersed through the remaining radius of the metal. Because of this, when the impact occurs on the 2nd gong, there would also be approximately 1 foot of air resistance before encountering a duplicate material where the first material removed most of it's kinetic energy through dispersion transfer. (Kinetic Energy transfer, much like electricity, will tend to take the path of least resistance, but only if certain conditions are met with KE, unlike electricity which always looks for the path of least resistance first.)

This one is interesting though, because although kinetic energy has been mostly dispersed into vibrational soundwave energy, the projectile did not lose as much velocity. So it is entirely possible that although the ball no longer has the kinetic energy to shatter the material the gong is made out of when it comes to the 2nd gong..... It definitely has the potential to warp it severely. This warp could prevent any remaining kinetic energy from transferring effectively to vibrational soundwave energy. So it is entirely possible that the 2nd gong may not make a sound at all when being hit, or rather make a very "flat" sound in addition to the very result of the impact on the 2nd gong being the cause as to why it doesn't penetrate it........ interesting. Well I hope they try it.

To the Captain America shield fans... ya... that's a no. Assuming Vibranium possesses the qualities of absorbing vibrational kinetic energy on the level of what a tectonic plate shift would produce overall before the wielder "feels it"... The baseball would shatter upon impact of the shield and it would look like a stiff breeze moved the shield slightly. Remember this thing can take artillery shell impacts and not have a scratch on it. A baseball moving at supersonic speeds is similar to an artillery shell impact, but far less dense and made out of a much softer material. :)

Alternatively, a more interesting theory I have is that a round shield made out of iron/composite would hold up better than say a Kite shield of the same material. Both are curved and meant to deflect impacts, but I believe the overall uniform shape of the shield would have more of a resistive effect in this instance rather than the material.

Finally, the maximum speed you can impact a gong with to make a sound depends on the material you hit it with, material of the gong, and how much vibration the struck material can handle before reaching a stress point where the material breaks down. Size of the gong and mallet matters also, they must be relative to each other. My theory is that the maximum hit speed (with it's relative counterpart striker, and NOT a baseball) should be about 775 mph, or just slightly over the speed of sound before you damage the gong to where it will not make the correct vibrational sound any longer.

If you've never tried a mylar mirror, it's time! My first contact was disassembling one of the old 3-crt reflector televisions that shoot their picture onto the back of a big fresnel lens. These TV's weighed 150# or so ... big old monsters, maybe 4' - 5' tall and 4' wide +/- They were beasts! I came across one at the city dump and just had to drag it home to see what's inside of the things. A quick search found that huge lightweight perfect mirrors for bedroom ceilings(!) were a thing. Bot my style, but now it's years later and I see another use for them. They can reflect sunlight as a beam for a long, long way. Perfect for your photo shoots.

Every instance of people shooting things at metal involves hardened metal, expecting hardness to have some extra ability to withstand sudden forces, but that's usually the opposite of what happens in the real world. I'm more curious about the difference between annealed metal and hardened metal when hit like that. Hardened metal, like the gong, isn't going to deform well under impact, but annealed metal may have a better chance of dissipating the force over the entire structure of the metal.

An MLB regulation baseball weighs between 142 and 149 grams. Call it 0.1455 kg average. 1189 mph = 531.53 m/sec. Kinetic energy = 1/2 mass times the square of the velocity = 0.7275  x 282,524.141 = 20,553.63 joules. To put this in perspective, let's compare to a firearm: the 30-06 rifle. Firing a 168 grain bullet at 2,750 feet per second, and converting all the units to metric, the muzzle energy of that rifle bullet is = (0.0108862 kg/2) x 838.2m/s^2 = 7648.43 joules. So, whatever this baseball hits, is going to experience 2.687 times the kinetic energy of a rifle bullet. So yeah, probably a good idea to not be standing anywhere downrange when the cannon is pressurized.

My thinking is that if you look, there seems to be a flash, like a minor ignition upon impact (look about 10:05). My guess just comes from the fact that the sprinkles are basically pure sugar, and even things that arent too keen on burning will go up if you aerosolize them. Not that its wise to discuss on the internet, but your standard granulated sugar and some weed killers (which I will not name for obvious reasons) can make some pretty potent chemicals which will ignite with interesting results, so rather than providing a chemical oxidiser, you compress them, which causes them to crack or become powder, which is ejected from the container, the initial shockwave of the baseball which you said was in excess of 1.5 mach might well be enough to create the compression necessary to burn the resulting powder, which could cause the flash and shockwave. The shockwave might also be the temperature differential from the flash?

Please excuse me if what I say is wrong, I last studied engineering a long time ago and its no longer my field of expertise (not that chemical science was ever my focus!)

Hey, just wanted to let you know what the shockwave was from. The force of the impact and the force of the propulsion meeting at the edge of the baseball as it bursts gives a minor Shockwave(soundwave) due to the buildup of the rubberbanding reverberating inside. Same when a person hits with a bat and gets that beautiful homerun hit sound. Should be able to still be visible there as well. But the shape of the ball makes it expel in a direct line due to the curve and materials. What you hear later is an echo off of that line. Depending on if you are in the lines path would debate on how far/well you would hear the noise produced.

Pulling the silly putty slowly, it stretches and deforms…. Gravity induced cold flow…
Pulling the putty quickly… it shatters…
Pulling, pushing, or deforming it at 1kmph it shatters into a million tiny pieces!

The sprinkles make an interesting flow study, as they are solid, but flow like a liquid… kind of laminar like….

The brass cymbal has a few deformations from its prior life… it is happy to deform, slowly…. Shatters like glass when hit by the speed ball….

Since you are using a baseball…. How do you control the curve ball? Does it get to the target before there is time drift?or is the momentum so large, the curve effect is not noticed…

I’m a big fan of laminar flow, and baseball….

One more thought here is to set up a series of balls inline with the "cannon baseball" and check on energy displacement.
In other words, as in the game of pool, you shoot one ball at another which should take the energy from the flying ball and transfer it to the sitting ball. The sitting ball will have to have the ability to move so a ridged track set up with the sitting ball at the very edge of the front end of the rack so that the flying ball will hit it squarely.
What should happen is the flying ball upon hitting the moveable sitting ball should lose most of its energy transferring it to the sitting ball which will then act as if it was now shot from the pneumatic cannon.
Another experiment would be to set up a series of sitting balls on the long track with spacing between them of say, a meter apart and let the energy transfer from one to the other.
The last ball would then or should then go from zero to whatever the diminished energy will allow it to travel.
A clocking device could be used to check the velocity.
Ok, thinking more about it...................a ball container filled with water so that the water stays in tact to the target.
In the military, we used IV bags between the C4 and the object we were trying to blast open. The water acted at a hydraulic piston forcing the object to be "pushed" rather than blown up.
This technique was opportune in opening a steel door.
Basically you are taking the energy of the pneumatic cannon and transferring it to a hydraulic piston.
Water can be compressed but very minutely. That's how they cut metal with it.

I think the reason the water droplets don't fall off the vertice stands of spider silk is a combination of friction, surface tension, leverage, and sag. Because the water droplet is forming on the silk the water finds a good catalyst point (defect in the web) and it just so happens that point has extremely high friction. Then once the droplet grows enough for gravity to start pulling on it I think the surface tension keeps the droplets from wetting the Web anymore and it creates a fulcrum and it pulls the web out and makes the web a bit more horizontal. It's definitely a delicate balance and awfully gorgeous.

Hi Destin, I have a Ph.D in post-impingement impingement fluid mechanics. The silly putty was interesting, in the early phases, the crown created seemed very similar to what we see in liquid, where the breakup is mainly dominated by the pressure in the fluid induced from the baseball impingement (And based on the conclusions of some papers, the ejecta breaking the sound-barrier). This makes sense, as a lot of the mathematics for liquids is derived from early military calculations for bullet and shell penetration of armour. However, at later timescales the breakup was very distinct, whereas in water or oil we would expect to see a  sheet, that with time breaks up under Rayleigh-Taylor instability However, with the silly putty, you could see that the crown material had already broken up into clumps. Now this could simply be because the impingements were supersonic, but it's a very different behaviour nonetheless!

For the record, the result with the gong was painfully obvious to every percussionist the world over. Gongs are notoriously sensitive and require being "warmed up" before striking by rubbing the mallet in a circular pattern on the gong to generate some vibration before the hard impact. Failure to do so will result in the gong getting stress fractures in no time.

10:07 The shockwave will be caused by the impact. At this point the high pressure air at the front of the ball (which forms the shock front) meets a solid surface and the pressure spikes, as the air can only move outwards now to escape. This causes the temperature to peak (we see a flash) and the gas will be accelerated radially outwards from the impact point, probably to much higher speeds than the baseball is travelling itself. This is in effect a tiny detonation so produces its own shockwave, which you spotted in the noisy footage.

I've gotta chime in on your "pole-to-pole" speed measurement.
From a perspective directly perpendicular from the gun (and in front of the first pole) you will know exactly when it crosses that pole. But for the second pole, it will appear to cross it earlier than it really does (in camera) because the perspective of it is skewed slightly (not perpendicular like pole 1).
I assume you acknowledged and adjusted to this... but just wanted to note it!

About the shock wave at 10:09. If you look there is a flash preceding the shock wave. My guess would be that there is a thermal bloom at the moment impact as kinetic energy dumps into the mass and heat is created at such speed that the thermal bloom radiating out from the point of impact is causing your shock wave. It just a guess but based on my understanding of ballistic impacts the initial impact causes heat as the molecules are accelerated in the target and they rub against each other. I remember a video about why they use aluminum in armored trucks instead of steel, it’s because the impact of the bullet causes a brief moment when the aluminum heats up and absorbs energy more like a liquid allowing more energy to propagate though a greater area reducing penetration. The part that stuck with me was the heat created by the impact would effectively allow a projectile to burn through steel, where the aluminum could absorb the heat energy into the armor plate. I think that wave we see in the noise is a thermal bloom.

Shock wave as baseball hits the can of sprinkles.  A round object traveling at subsonic speeds has a bow wave, which may yet compress and squirt out the sides at supersonic velocities upon impact.  When the round object is traveling at supersonic speeds, it's already compressed.  However, it's not infinitely compressed.  There's still a bit of a subsonic bow wave!  That, too, squirts out the sides upon impact, obviously at supersonic speeds.

Hey Destin. Thought I would try this side of the comment sectio . I have a question that maybe you can help me answer. I'm studying to become a commercial pilot and as far as I can tell, the future of commercial aviation (in the long run) is fully electric aircraft. I'm excited to see the use of Solid-state batteries, or Glass packs, in all types of tech but especially aircraft. A lighter, safer, and more powerful battery sounds very exciting to me. I am a little bit surprised that the huge shock wave created by the baseball is not completely visible in the sunshine, or maybe it is in some other pictures. When shooting ordinary high power rifles with the sun coming from behind, we could easily see the bullet travel - the shock wave reflecting sunshine - through a spotting scope. Also, when shooting rifles in the rain, it was easy to see the bullet path from any angle because the shock wave shattered all the nearby rain drops, even though there were few drops and the bullet was not actually hitting them. It would be fun to see these effects with the much larger baseball, but I do not know if the baseball flight distance is long enough.

Hi, in the interest of being smarter every day I'd like to inform you that the gong you have is not actually a gong! It is in fact a tam tam. The difference between gongs and tam tams is that of definite pitch; whether there is a distinct note upon striking. Gongs are pitched, tam tams are not, the sound of the instrument you have here is unpitched, and therefore it is a tam tam!
Thank you for the science, happy hunting!

MAJOR "The Matrix" vibes with that last shot. It puts into perspective how advanced the Wachowski's cinematography, effects and creativity were back then. Incredible shots, Destin and crew!

In regards to the mirror looking like water, that's because glass is technically a solid liquid. So, it would look like water when exposed to extreme stress or at extreme speeds. (like shooting it with a supersonic baseball cannon)

Basically, glass is never solid, it is just moving VERY VERY slowly; like you'll never notice in your lifetime (unless you measured it) slowly.

Also, when it's molten (like in the glass hot shop at the place where I work) it very quickly will revert to a more solid state, but it still is a liquid, just more evident because it is in an extreme circumstance. (like shooting glass with a supersonic baseball cannon)

Hopefully that helps to explain that question a little bit. (especially since it's late when I'm writing this) :D

9:45 I have a suuuper basic understanding of cameras and even less of an understanding of science, but isn't a visible shock wave a result from heat and pressure changing how light is refracted, thus creating an observable imperfection in the frame. Since a noise reduction program/algorithm is designed to reduce light imperfections in a frame, I would guess that the program is confusing the shock wave with noise/imperfections and it is smoothing it all out using known, good pixels and causing you to lose small details.

This just a guess, I'm the furthest person away from being a camera expert. I just know that the best way to reduce digital noise in a camera shot is to add more light, either by re-framing, artificially adding more light, or by allowing more light to hit the sensor (opening up the aperture).

Fun fact about gongs:  when playing a gong (with a mallet not a supersonic baseball) the percussionist will lightly tap the gong with the mallet to get it vibrating (but not audibly) this is so when they hit it loudly it is less of a shock to the metal and it is much less likely to crack. RE: the sprinkles all shattering: when they're all in the jug together at impact, every sprinkle has multiple points of contact with other sprinkles, and they're all at least semi-rigid. What you're seeing is the acoustic waves of the impact exciting all of the sprinkles like the molecules of a solid going straight to vapor/plasma phase but ~10^22ish times bigger in scale. At least, that's what it looks like to me.

That question about the droplets on the spider web is actually an interesting question. I've used wire to apply a line of super glue droplets to apply dots of superglue in a straight line (to be dusted with baking soda as grip texture on guitar picks).  But, getting the drop size right is a pain, and the drops will merge if they're too big.  I actually bought an ultra-light guitar string to use as the wire in the hopes that I could consistently get small drops (no luck).  Should have used a custom applicator of some kind.  Anyway, those spider web strands are the sticky part at an angle, and there must be something about the surface that holds the beads of water but doesn't really wet the strand such that it spreads or slides.  But, I bet if the droplets get to big... Curious.

No matter what the pressure is, you cannot accelerate any projectile to speeds faster than the speed of molecules of the respective gas - which is roughly speed of sound (that's where the speed of sound comes from). You either need to heat the gas up or use gas with lighter and faster molecules. For example hydrogen or helium.

Spider web holds onto those droplets of water like that because those particular strands are the adhesive catching strands of the web. The only difference between the primary frame strands and the catching strands are that the catching strands have a string of ~10 nanometer adhesive droplets purposefully applied down their length at regular intervals as they are extruded. These droplets act as points around which surface tension can draw the water to gather.
If you have access to a SEM, I think you could probably take a rather deep dive on spider web and spiders in general. The mechanism of the spinneret is especially fascinating, but they also have different types of webbing spigots on their feet. Would make for a very interesting video topic.

If I had to guess about the spider web, I have three thoughts. 1) The droplets are small enough that the glue-like properties of thin films of water are keeping it in place - just like how sand castles work. You can actually test this by applying vibration to it and seeing if they fall. 2) There is an interaction between the silk and the droplet on a microscopical level where the psycical structure of the silk is supporting the droplet. Possibly testable with a microscope. 3) The silk is chemically interacting with the droplet to form some bond. No idea how you might easily test this. It should also be noted that some strands are structural and some are functional, meaning they have different properties and compositions which makes chemical bonding the least compelling option if the droplets are evenly dispersed across all strands

The shockwave that you're seeing in the background at 10:09 is probably "Background Oriented Schlieren Imaging" by accident. BOS is based on finding the difference in pixel intensities from a shockwave distorting the static (random) background. With the noise removed, you've essentially removed that random difference that allows the shockwave to appear. BOS is how you can see shockwaves off of airplanes in certain images. Search for "f-18 shockwave san fansisco airshow" and look for the image of the Blue Angel plane with the tail number 5.

Hey Destin, great video as ever! The reason each sprinkle split appart because the compressive impulse imparted to it, travels through the sprinkle. When the compressive impulse wave reaches the edge of the sprinkle that is not in contact with another that it can transfer energy to, it is reflected internally as a tensile wave. These waves propergate and are reflected in-turn as compressive waves. This process repeats until the energy is dissipated. Due to the shape of the object, the patterns of reflective waves become very complex. Where two or more waves cross paths, the amplitude is cumulative. When the amplitute of tensile waves are greater than the tensile strength of the material, a fracture will occur. The waves continue to reflect and ocilate between compressive and tensile waves within the remaining pieces and they may fracture too. The mechanics of reflecting compressive/tensile waves can be observed in a Newton's Craddle. It is the same reason that when a projectile hits a brittle material, material spalls out the back side of the material. The British navy used to classify the power of a cannon by shooting a cannon ball at the end of a log and counting how many times the log fractured. It would be amazing if you could do this with your baseball cannon!

Kind Regards

10:10 could that be a Mach stem? Nuclear warheads are detonated above ground level so that the shockwave reflects off the surface and interacts with the initial shockwave. The two constructively interfere and create a combined shockwave with higher pressure which is called a Mach stem. In the video, the shockwave from the supersonic ball could bounce off the jar and interfere with the shockwave following the ball creating a Mach stem. You could test my idea by firing the ball past a solid object and seeing if you observe the same visual effect on the side where the object is.

Hey destin, I’m pretty sure the water sticks to the web because The silk with which the spider spins its web is made of nano fibrils of about 20 to 30 nano-meter in diameter. These nano fibrils form aligned structure at the joints and a messed up random puff at every 85.6 micro meter on the thread. This randomness makes the puff have a higher free surface energy and more wetability. As the temperature of environment around the spider web falls below dew point, water starts condensing on the silk threads. The puffs transform to spindle like structures (Like two cones connected at their bases with the axis running through the silk thread). These spindle like structures then attract the minute water droplets due to two forces
1: force due to surface energy gradient
2: force due to Laplace pressure gradient

Hey Destin there's something I've been wondering for a while now after seeing several of your videos where you have (normal) glass shattering in slow motion. The shattering of the glass seems impossibly fast: I can watch really fast moving objects with your phantom recordings but I can't seem to watch a crack forming in glass. One moment there's no crack, the next there's all kinds of cracks all the way from the impact point to every side of the glass.

This video there was a difference: At 19:40 (31.333 ms) if you go frame by frame you can see what looks like a perfectly circle of cracks in all directions for a split second, before there are again cracks all the way to the edge of the glass. Now I don't know if that's just due to the recording or if there are other reasons. If I had to take I guess I think the perfect circle of cracks is due to the mirror actually caving in when the baseball hits, and the rest of the cracks are the resulting stress fractures.

If I've got you wondering the same thing now and you want to do a video, I've got four basic questions:
#1: How fast does a crack in glass "travel"? It really seems very fast: 31.267 ms = impact? 31.333 ms = perfect circle of cracks covering 1/4? of the mirror. 31.400 ms = visible cracks across the entire mirror.
#2: Does the crack "travel" at all? In other words can you see a crack start somewhere and work it's way in a direction, or does a crack (at least visibly) form along it's entire length simultaneously.
#3: Is there any use to this knowledge aside from it being really cool to learn about God's creation?
#4: Prince Rupert's drops obviously behave differently, since they are smelted differently and I've actually seen the shattering travel along a prince Rupert's drop in your videos. So my question is: Do cracks travel faster or slower in panned glass or a Prince Rupert's drop? Do Prince Rupert's drops even crack, or is there some kind of difference in terminology and effect in the way a Prince Rupert's drop breaks as compared to a normal glass pane?

If that's not enough I've got three more questions about glass shattering:

#5: Why do most cracks intersect either with an edge or another crack but a very few have one end be floating free? Also, why is it always only one end? Why can't I ever recall glass having just a floating crack where both ends don't touch either the edge of the glass or another crack? Also if you look at 31.800 ms, on the left hand side there a larger shard with two such "one ended" cracks and a very small gap in between them. How in the world did those two cracks not propagate into each other?
#6: Why are glass shards almost always pointed at at least one point on their circumference (i.e Pizza slice shaped) and sharp enough to cut as well? How come you don't hear about dull glass shards? Do dull glass shards exist?
#7: Why do some areas of a shattering glass pane get covered in dozens of cracks while others are simply large shards with few to no cracks? Is it simply due to varying material strength or is it due to the way the stress propagates through the glass? An example can be seen at 31.800 ms on the right side, there are three larger shards with strips of dozens of cracks between each of the larger shards.

Now I realize I could look up a good chunk of this online but I figure if you do a video on it then I may learn more and thousands of other people get to learn as well ;)

Keep it up Destin, your videos embody my desire to learn about the world. It's great to see how many others are out there who are like minded :)

But the shockwave from the sprinkles, is that from the conflagration/slight detonation you get from the baseball hitting the container? We see that flash, which obviously is a release of energy, but then the baseball is rushing in to the same space, displacing and extinguishing it. Could that be a small explosion of the front of the super sonic air pressure the ball is creating impacting, exploding/bursting, and then being thrown out of the way by the baseball? I'd normally just say an explosion, but that little pop doesn't seem to be enough to create a shockwave of that size. It would almost seem more plausible that the super sonic air pressure of the ball is reacting to being stopped and then the ball somehow disrupts that, otherwise you'd think that the super heated impact and the powderization of the sprinkles would cause a fireball.

That could also, slight possibility, be the ripple you saw across the mirror. While you've cleaned it up, the mirror does provide more light data, meaning what might be only visible in the noise becomes more apparent with that much more light and frames. Just theories, not anything solid. Great stuff.

What you guys ought to do is make a blast redirector. What I'm envisioning just looks like a 45 degree ramp with a decent size (30-60cm) hole in it, and a falling solid flap that covers the hole when a support is blown out. Inertia keeps everything out of the way of the projectile, but when the gasses arrive the supports have already blown out and the flap is on it's way down. Some gas will proceed through the closing hole, but not enough to mess with your equipment downrange. The remainder is deflected upwards harmlessly.

Could also have the door counterweighted/sprung and not fully open, just clear of the opening. The gas flow would just push it shut, and it would reset afterwards.

What amazed me the most from the mirror shot was seeing the baseball flying with absolutely zero rotation.  It just seemed counter-intuitive to me, but the more I thought about it I ended up realizing that is what the spiral rifling in a barrel does to a bullet.  Without it, there is no spin and so you loose accuracy over longer distances.  Since you are not trying for distance accuracy, it isn't that much of an issue for your cannon.

OK, let's put this into perspective. A baseball travelling at mach 1.5 carries so much kinetic energy it destroys just about everything in its path besides inches thick steel.

Now picture the International Space Station, orbiting our Earth at almost 400km altitude, travelling at mach 25, and weighing a few hundred tons. E = 0.5 * m * v^2 also means that the kinetic energy gained is quadratic relative to the speed of the object. Now THAT's a lot of kinetic energy, and now one also understands why we need such massive rockets to get a little payload into orbit. Yet the Saturn V launched men beyond earth orbit and to the moon in 1969!

A dear departed friend would produce shock waves in order to map the pressure fronts produced by bombs. The problem was using a valve, like you have on your cannon, only produced a a pressure front not a shock wave. He overcame this by having a kevlar sheet disk that had slots cut in a pattern that was designed to burst at various pressures. The fewer cuts the higher the pressure and vis versa. I think, by using this shock wave effect combined with your negative pressure in the barrel the effect could increase your projectile speed considerably, for considerably see 'kin whacks, ( Cornish for, a lot). quick note about gongs: typically gongs are "warmed up" before playing, usually you want to try and lightly tap the gong at least a few times before before playing it, as striking the instrument cold has a bit of delay to the sound (big metal plate takes a while for vibrations to travel through them). this seemed to be a smaller one, though really any cymbal that big is usually warmed up before playing.


i don't know as much with the physics technicalities (i just play instruments lol), though i'm curious to see if the gong would have had a different physical/aural response to the ball if it had already been vibrating before impact. i've heard from a lot of other musicians/clinicians that going in cold on larger gongs/tam-tams before playing loud impacts can also cause them to crack, though i've also heard some people say this is complete bogus.

Baseballs and cricket balls are EXACTLY THE SAME, except for the stitching. Same weight. Same shape. Same diameter. Same materials. ONLY THE STITCHING pattern is different. For very understandable reason (similar strain rates), the deformation of the gong is very similar (near identical) to “explosive forming” which is used to “cold form” metals to strain levels well beyond the metal’s Max failure strain.
By deforming the metal really, really fast, it will stretch to deformations (ie., “strains”) that the metal could not survive if it were deformed slowly.

I got a theory for the sprinkles exploding the way they did around 9:40

I’m thinking it’s kinda like how energy is transferred in a Newtons Cradle. If you look at the sprinkles as the ball is starting to go through the container, look at the first sprinkles that start to explode then start looking at the sprinkles touching it and you’ll see that they are still mostly intact until the the first sprinkles are disintegrated at which point the next sprinkles are disintegrated and so on until they are all mostly dust.

That and when the ball first hits the container, but before it explodes, the container builds up internal pressure which causes the sprinkles to be under much more than atmospheric pressure. Since they are fairly ridged and brittle, the extra pressure starts to crush them before the Newtons cradle effect comes in to play.

Finally, since these are going faster than the speed of sound, I’m thinking the pressure at the front of the ball is assisting everything I just mentioned.

Now I wonder if the sprinkles will act the same way in a non-airtight container. Perhaps put them in a ziplock bag with gussets (fill it all the way to the top and leave the zipper open all the way) then put cheesecloth or something like that on top of it so most of the sprinkles are still forced to go through their container. Then try and see if you can build something to hold an open pile of sprinkles and see how they act like that too.

I’m sure that I am not the only one here that would love to see that comparison.

I would like to add one thing, I am not a scientist so take what I said with a grain of salt. I may be missing some critical point that would instantly debunk everything I just said. Still, I think my theory makes sense, well makes sense to me anyway.

Can I just point out how amazing the drone stabilization software is? That little drone gets pummeled by a shockwave created by a super sonic object, and just recovers like boss. It does this over and over and over. Each time a shockwave hits the aerodynamics of the propeller blades is completely thrown out the window, at some point part of a propeller will suddenly be in an increased atmosphere, while at the same time another part of the propeller will be in a reduced pressure situation. This effect washes over the whole drone disrupting all the propellers differently, not to mention the shock wave pushing and pulling on the drone's body. By all rights that poor little thing should get swatted out of the air like a mosquito in a tornado.

For the shockwave emanating out from the sprinkles bottle, It would be interesting to see if that shockwave propagates out in a sphere even if the angle of incidence of the impact is increased.  That shockwave makes me thing of the circular impacts of meteor craters and I wonder if the shockwave is produced from the energy of the impact exploding outward, or the reflection of the pressure wave in front of the ball.  The prediction would be: if the ball impacts the sprinkles at a 45 deg angle, the shock wave will be biased down range if it is due to reflection.  If it is due to the energy of the impact exploding outward it should be roughly spherical and only marginally impacted by the pressure wave moving down range.

Hello Destin, you and your team are doing amazing. However, I believe that you really should add a critical part to this amazing canon. You see, the issue is that once the baseball exit the canon, it is followed by so much pressurized air which was inside the chamber, which is not necessarily helpful. Therefore, you and your team should build something like a "jet-engine thrust reverser." The main point of this thrust reverser or let us call it a pressurized air converter is to convert the pressurized air to both sides so it would not destroy the outcome of baseball damage on any certain object. For instance, in today's video, the baseball punctured the gong and it was standing still just fine until that high-pressurized airwave came and hit the gong sending it flying and then got destroyed. If there was a pressurized air converter, the gong would not be destroyed.
Hope this idea of a pressurized air converter would help to make this experiment extra informative and more enjoyable.
Cheers and God bless you all.

7:20 The spider silk has hydrophilic parts in the protein, the dew forms centered on them, but if it's not a wetted part, it's not easily wetted. It's probably an evolutionary thing that helped spiders get water without risking drowning. Surface tension is a big issue when you're that small, the surface tension of the water is higher than the force you can exert to pull yourself out, so if one part gets wetted, you're going to get stuck, many araneomorphs get their air through spiracles, rather than book lungs, so even if they do get out of a puddle, they're going to drown, or at least be a lot slower. Not having to go to the ground for water also means they're less likely to get stepped on or hunted by ground predators, at least when they're in their webs, birds usually stay clear of them.
I have observed the same silk wetting phenonmenon with my mygalomorph spiders, both tarantulaes and funnelwebs, but to a lesser extent. though the tarantula's web seems to have something soluble in it, which acts as a surfactant, allowing the water to basically turn into a bubble and cover the gap between the web, I've seen her drink from it. She's a desert tarantula, so maybe something to do with stopping moisture from leaving her burrow, or efficient collection of dew? She still has a water dish and she will drink from that if I haven't misted her cage in a while. But it's a really cool phenomenon, I'd like to check how other webs react, but I can only get native Australian spiders here.

TL;DR it's just that only certain points on the silk strand are easily wetted, all the dew that forms flows to those points, if they oversaturate, they drop off.
